ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A good baseline of the Spanish language.
I learned basic Spanish vocabulary and grammar.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: As a leg of a much larger department, the class felt so rehearsed and stilted that we didn't get much out of the actual classtime. Peer conversation practice was good, but the learning happened independently in the textbook, and the powerpoints didn't do anything more than restate the learning of the previous night. Tests, too, were sent down from department heads so our teacher couldn't answer basic questions without checking in with her superiors.
Strength: being taught every day is a necessity when learning a new language, and the variety of exercises definitely helped. The fact that you get essay rewrites is also a plus.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I mean, it does the job. Profesora Uemura didn't really help or hurt the process, but I did feel like most of the learning came out of the textbook. Worth taking if you want to learn Spanish, but the course isn't anything to write home about.
If you're looking for a place to learn Spanish, SPAN 110 is the place!
If you want to start learning Spanish, yes.
